fields.headline: In praise of … pizza
fields.bodyText: It is possibly the most traduced national dish in the world, so often almost indistinguishable from the cardboard box in which it is delivered. But that is the fate of pizza: in the right hands, the food of the gods, but also a global comfort food – so much so that technologists have spent years trying to find a way of getting an approximation of it into soldiers' ration packs. It is a tough ask: the right dough, the right heat, the right topping, all converted into something that can be stored for weeks at a time and emerge edible at the end of it. But, just as they prepare to pull out of Afghanistan, word comes that this new scientific milestone has been achieved. At a charity dinner organised by the Guardian in Kabul, where brave paying guests dined off a meal from the army rations of every country that has soldiers based there, once again the Italian menu was favourite. It did start with an advantage: it was the only one that included a shot of grappa.
